data.title: [1.19.0-beta1] Block decorations mess up line numbering on scrolling
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If multiple block decorations are shown, line numbers get into an inconsistent state after scrolling

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open file with a few lines of code
2. Execute the following code in dev tools and observe correct line number callculation:
```js
function createBlock(row) {
  const item = document.createElement("span");
  item.innerText = "[block decoration]\n[block decoration]\n[block decoration]";
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor();
  const marker = editor.markBufferPosition([row, 0]);
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, { type: "block", item: item });
}

createBlock(1);
createBlock(5);
createBlock(8);
createBlock(10);
```
3. Scroll and observe inconsistent line numbers

**Expected behavior (Atom 1.18):** Line numbers are preserved by block decorations during scrolling

**Actual behavior (Atom 1.19-beta1):**
![line-number](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13285808/27329042-6e4bf9cc-55b4-11e7-92e1-5ff61c55029e.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%
### Versions

macOS
```bash
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

This bug is especially critical for [Hydrogen](https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen/) since we render live results from a running kernel inside a block decoration, that can change dimensions over time.

Possibly related: #14817

data.title: :bug: Don't prefix resource path if package path is already absolute
data.body:
We're running into an issue in Nuclide where sometimes `finishLoading()` is called twice on the `tree-view` package. As a result, the path gets prepended twice.

This doesn't fix the underlying bug, but I think it's still best to use `resolve()` here so that, if `@path` is absolute, the resource path won't be prepended multiple times.

data.title: [1.19-beta] Block decorations don't remeasure if content changes
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

First of all congratulations on the awesome improvements in the latest Atom releases, that's a great leap forward 💯 

Though it looks like a bug in the new editor rendering rewrite (#13880) slipped through regarding block decoration rendering.

The height of a block decorations doesn't get recalculated anymore if the content changes.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Place cursor in the middle of a file
2. Execute the following code in the console and observe odd rendering:
```js
const item = document.createElement("span")
const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
const cursorRow = editor.getCursorBufferPosition().row
const marker = editor.markBufferPosition([cursorRow, 0])
editor.decorateMarker(marker, { type: "block", item: item })
setTimeout(() => {
  item.innerText = "[block decoration]\n[block decoration]\n[block decoration]\n[block decoration]"
}, 100)
```
3. Resize window to see layout recalculation and correct rendering

**Expected behavior (Atom 1.18):**
![1 18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13285808/27311181-846d3ea0-555f-11e7-920d-6412308f1fe2.gif)

**Actual behavior (Atom 1.19 and `master`):**
![block](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13285808/27311186-8d1fc11c-555f-11e7-9303-c1fb5cde4aee.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

macOS
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
and
```
Atom    : 1.20.0-dev-ccdae0fc8
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

This bug is especially critical for [Hydrogen](https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen/) since we render live results from a running kernel inside a block decoration, that can change dimensions over time.

data.title: Launching Atom opens a new instance even if an instance is already running
data.body:
### Description

Not necessarily a bug, but I think that most people would expect for the existing editor window to be maximized, rather than a whole new instance/window opening. If I have Atom pinned to the taskbar and Atom is currently running, when I click the pinned icon again, a new instance opens. Since this also happens when running Atom from the Start Menu, the issue would probably happen using any method of launching.

### Steps to Reproduce

Edit: Just go to the Start Menu, run Atom, then repeat

1. Windows is configured to show taskbar icons only on the monitor where an application is opened (see screenshot @ https://vgy.me/EFxAG1.png)
2. Open Atom
3. Pin Atom to Taskbar
4. Move Atom window to another monitor
5. Now your taskbar button for Atom is in that monitor's taskbar, and the pinned launcher is still on your primary monitor
6. Click the pinned Atom launcher icon again

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The existing Atom instance in the other monitor is focused/maximized

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

A new instance of Atom opens

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

1.18.0 x64

### Description

There is an option to `Enable/disable` automatic updates but there is no option to download update manually. Once we click on `Check for Updates` the update starts downloading automatically.

Go Atom -> Check for Updates

Once the user checks for update, the newer version gets downloaded

Atom Version: 1.18.0

I tested in macOS Sierra

data.title: Atom showing tab characters in teal for .eslintrc, forcing spaces
data.body:
I'm using Atom 1.18.0 ia32.

I'm creating a new project and put in an `.eslintrc` file, copied from another project. I modified the file and changed the spaces to tabs:

```json
{
	"extends": "eslint:recommended",
	"env": {
		"es6": true,
		"browser": true,
		"node": true,
		"mocha": true
	}
}
```

Atom shows all the tab characters with a teal-ish background color (regardless of whether I show or hide invisibles). This does not happen in e.g. `package.json` or `.jsbeautifyrc`.

On top of this, when I hit `<tab>` in `.package.json` or `.jsbeautifyrc`, I get a tab character, but in `.eslintrc` I get two spaces --- even though I have changed `.eslintrc` to use tabs, and reloaded the file (and restarted Atom).

What is different about the `.eslintrc` file that Atom wants to change the colors of the tab characters and force spaces instead of tabs?

In my Atom config I have:
* Soft Tabs: (unselected)
* Tab Type: auto

data.title: Option key is not honored in key bindings when combined with Ctrl
data.body:
I recently upgraded Atom to 1.18.0 on Mac.  Not sure about the exact version number before the upgrade, but probably 1.16.x.

Since the update, the Option key on Mac seems to be ignored in key bindings when pressed with the Ctrl key.  For example, if I press Ctrl-Opt-G, Ctrl-G is executed (which is bound to "Go to Line").  Also, if I press Ctrl-Opt-L, Ctrl-L is executed (which is bound to "Clear Console").

This is problematic, because I have defined Ctrl-Opt-G and Ctrl-Opt-L as the shortcuts to input some unicode characters (Greek letters γ and λ).

Is it possible to make Atom honor the Option key when pressed with the Ctrl key?

data.title: [v1.19-beta] Creating block decoration on manually created editor make editor rendering odd.
data.body:
Same issue of already closed #14743
Also might be related to this #14811

![block-decoration-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/27255493-eaba6d7c-53d9-11e7-8507-bcf742a84494.gif)

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Creating block decoration at manually created editor make editor rendering odd.

- In v1.18: no issue
- In v1.19-beta: have issue(so editor rendering degradation?)

Additionally
- If I open item by `workspace.open(item)`: issue happen
- If I open item by `pane.activateItem(item)`: issue NOT happen
- Although, both have un-scrollable issue described in #14811

### Steps to Reproduce

1. launch atom in safe mode.
2. Open dev-console and paste code below.
  - it create editor and put 100 lines text
  - And add block decoration at point [0, 0]

```javascript
(function reproduceIssue() {
  const {TextEditor} = require("atom")
  const editor = new TextEditor()

  // case-1: Open with workspace.open
  atom.workspace.open(editor)

  // case-2: Open with pane.activateItem
  //   If I opened by pane.activateItem, this rendering odd is not happens.
  //   But still can't scroll though
  // const pane = atom.workspace.getActivePane().splitRight()
  // pane.activateItem(editor)

  const lines = []
  for (let i = 1; i < 100; i++) {
    lines.push(i)
  }
  editor.insertText(lines.join("\n"))
  editor.setCursorBufferPosition([0, 0])

  // Add blockdecoration at point [0, 0]
  const item = document.createElement("div")
  item.innerText = "[block decoration]"
  const marker = editor.markBufferPosition([0, 0])
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, {type: "block", item: item})
})()
```

3. see text is inserted at different line where cursor is displayed.


### Versions

macOS
```
ProductName:	Mac OS X
ProductVersion:	10.12.5
```

Atom
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

I noticed this issue while I'm investigating slowness of beta when opening manually created editor on my atom-narrow package.
Opening manually created editor is slower than atom-stable, not fully investigated yet(maybe this rendering issue might be cause of slowness).

data.title: git.exe consuming lots of memory and putting cursor in indefinite progress state.
data.body:
Hi,

I recently installed atom after uninstalling it on windows 10 , as earlier it was running a process called `git for windows` which was consuming a lot of memory .Now when I try to open atom  ,I am getting this error:


![atom_error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20846397/27243573-347ccb24-5300-11e7-83c4-9d4878028e24.jpg)



OK .Somehow I get rid of this but now:

When I open atom there's a process in Task manager which is creating all the gotchas.It starts seconds after starting atom.This is located at : C:\Users\...\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.18.0\resources\app\node_modules\dugite\git\mingw64\bin\git.exe. 
This process consumes lots of memory & causes cursor to be in progress state indefinitely,


![prob](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20846397/27247094-807f1abe-5313-11e7-990f-70b3e94e7099.jpeg)

I am not sure why this started all of a sudden .Is this a default process?

**TEMP. SOLUTION**:
I ended the task from task manager .
Closed atom .
Deleted git.exe file.
And now I am not facing this problem, atleast .
